channel.title: Scar Scripting Standards Tutorial and Other Info
channel.description:
[center][b][size=15pt]Scar Scripting Standards and Other Info[/size][/b][/center]
Bad Standards! [img]http://img291.imageshack.us/img291/9666/badstandardsqq2.jpg[/img]
Try that code. As you can see, it works, but if you ever wanted to change something in it, then it would be a hassle. That is just a very small peice of code I concocked very quickly, but you should see other people's cose. 300 or 400 lines of code, and it doesn't have good coding standards. Here is a good example of the script I just showed you, with good standards.
Good Standards! [img]http://img154.imageshack.us/img154/2738/goodstandardsxe9.jpg[/img]
It's very simple. Here are the rules.
[ul][*] Tree your code AKA display the code in a neat format. Example...[/ul] [code] Begin Repeat WriteLn('wow'); Until(False) End. [/code] Another Example only this time we used Tab to tree the code: [code] Begin Repeat WriteLn('wow'); Until(False) End. [/code] [ul][*] Try to comment most parts of it, that way it's easier to find where you left off from and it's easier for someone else to debug your code. [*] Try to make everything user friendly. Take the first code's instructions on the Const setup. It wasn't too descriptive. [*] Use procedures instead of putting all your code right in between the Begin and End. commands. [*] Use ; at the end of each command such as... WriteLn('asdkjaskldj'); and SendKeys('asdasdasds'); [*] Try to keep functions and procedures in the proper case. Such as the procedure WriteLn. Don't write it like writeln. Same with IntToStr and StrToInt and the 1000s of others.[/ul]
I hope you learned something. :)
~Ron
PS: Yeah I know the Const doesn't affect the script at all. It was just there to show you, how you can make it neat and show you how to setup the instructions for other people.

item.title: Scar Scripting Standards Tutorial and Other Info
item.dc:creator: @wixter wixter
item.description:
@wixter wrote:

very nice tutorial for newcommers, gj

Read full topic

item.title: Scar Scripting Standards Tutorial and Other Info
item.dc:creator: @Ron Ron
item.description:
@Ron wrote:

[quote=“KyleGut3, post:2, topic:4980”]Sure it looks pretty, but your constants do not do what they say and you ran an infinite loop.

Nice tut Ron :).[/quote]
Thanks Kyle, but I knew that. I was just trying to show every part of code people normally use. I forgot If statements though. And besides. You get the point.

Also, thank you thief. If any of you guys sees someone without using standards, just link them to this tutorial!

~Ron

Read full topic
item.source: Scar Scripting Standards Tutorial and Other Info

item.title: Scar Scripting Standards Tutorial and Other Info
item.dc:creator: @thiefmn6092 thiefmn6092
item.description:
@thiefmn6092 wrote:

[quote=“Ron, post:1, topic:4980”][center][size=15pt]Scar Scripting Standards and Other Info[/size][/center]

Bad Standards!

Try that code. As you can see, it works, but if you ever wanted to change something in it, then it would be a hassle. That is just a very small peice of code I concocked very quickly, but you should see other people’s cose. 300 or 400 lines of code, and it doesn’t have good coding standards. Here is a good example of the script I just showed you, with good standards.

Good Standards!

It’s very simple. Here are the rules.

[ul][*] Tree your code AKA display the code in a neat format. Example…[/ul]

Begin
 Repeat
  WriteLn('wow');
 Until(False)
End.

Another Example only this time we used Tab to tree the code:

Begin
     Repeat
           WriteLn('wow');
     Until(False)
End.

[ul][] Try to comment most parts of it, that way it’s easier to find where you left off from and it’s easier for someone else to debug your code.
[] Try to make everything user friendly. Take the first code’s instructions on the Const setup. It wasn’t too descriptive.
[] Use procedures instead of putting all your code right in between the Begin and End. commands.
[] Use ; at the end of each command such as… WriteLn(‘asdkjaskldj’); and SendKeys(‘asdasdasds’);
[*] Try to keep functions and procedures in the proper case. Such as the procedure WriteLn. Don’t write it like writeln. Same with IntToStr and StrToInt and the 1000s of others.[/ul]

I hope you learned something.

~Ron[/quote]

Nice tut Ron, I’ll throw you some cookies.

Read full topic
item.source: Scar Scripting Standards Tutorial and Other Info

Here is a good example of the script I just showed you, with good standards.

It’s very simple. Here are the rules.

Begin

Begin

[ul][] Try to comment most parts of it, that way it’s easier to find where you left off from and it’s easier for someone else to debug your code.
[] Try to make everything user friendly. Take the first code’s instructions on the Const setup. It wasn’t too descriptive.

[] Use ; at the end of each command such as… WriteLn(‘asdkjaskldj’); and SendKeys(‘asdasdasds’);
[*] Try to keep functions and procedures in the proper case. Such as the procedure WriteLn. Don’t write it like writeln. Same with IntToStr and StrToInt and the 1000s of others.[/ul]

I hope you learned something.

~Ron

PS: Yeah I know the Const doesn’t affect the script at all. It was just there to show you, how you can make it neat and show you how to setup the instructions for other people.
